content.description: We had to knock a large dead log out of the way to open up the base of the corner. It started to clean up nicely. With a few more laps, most of the rotten rock will be gone.
content.protection: Small to medium cams and nuts. Build a gear anchor for your second, and walk off to climber's right. I will add anchors the next time I am up there.
content.location:
This ascends the corner just to the left of

No Armin It

.

content.description: This is a funky face with a hollow pillar that doesn't protect well at all on lead.  A TR is better.  You can ascend up the groove and then either right or left of the pillar.  Note, you should be careful not to apply much force outward on the pillar.  It flexes at least an inch.  A star is probably generous.

This is the slab to the right of

Armin Dillo

.  There are probably still a few loose holds.
content.protection: Light rack.  To #4 Camalot if you pro the dihedral to start.
content.location:
This is to the right of

Armin Dillo

.

content.description: This is a tiny line on the left side. It basically shoots for a crack through a bulge on funky, bulbous holds. This has 40' of climbing to 30' of 4th Class terrain for an anchor. A star is probably generous.
content.protection: To #4 Camalot. A #9 hex was useful.
content.location: This is on the left side of the crag.

content.description:
This is an obvious dihedral.  ~40' of climbing, then 15' of 3rd class to a tree.

Interestingly, there was a watch buried under pine needles partway up the route.  It was only about 5.4 to that point, so it probably is from a hiker.
This is a blunt arete just left of an obvious dihedral.  You can anchor off a tree above.
content.location: This is left of the dihedral in the photo.

content.description:
Climb a face to a short squeeze slot, which is visible in the upper-right corner of the

Armin Left

beta photo. This does not have the best granite.
content.location:
It is just left of

Arm in Trouble

.

content.description: I think this route is the best at this crag. It has about twenty feet of steep crack and interesting holds. I avoided the best hold, a loose horn just left of the crux section. Using it would have made everything easier but could have killed my belayer or my dog. I could thus insufficiently reach a crucial handjam.
content.protection: I placed a #1 and slung a blob on the scramble to the crack. I placed a #4, 0.5, 0.75, and a 0.5. I used a #0.3 and a #9 hex for the anchor in the base of the summit boulder.
content.location: This is on a short pinnacle on the far left of the crag. Thirty feet of careful scrambling reaches the obvious crack.

content.description:
Looking through the new Boulder Canyon guidebook reminded me of doing two undocumented routes that I climbed at Armin’s. In October 2013, I led the face that is about five or six feet left of

Armin Left

. It is visible in the beta photo of

Armin Left

.

This route doesn’t have the best granite. Pro was placed in the occasional incipient cracks, including next to the small, triangular overhang that appears about halfway up. Continue straight up, finding occasional pro and using both short cracks visible at the top. I recall that a set-back short wall was climbed above what is visible in the photo.

Descend by walking off.
content.protection: A standard rack plus additional small and tiny gadgets. I might have placed small Tri-cams.
content.location:
Start about five or six feet left of

Armin Left

, assuming that

AL

climbs to and up the crack that is near the center of said photo.
